bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Albert E. Truby, February 4, 1950

div1.p: Lambert promotes the work that Ames did in caring for yellow fever patients during the experiments. He thinks Ames did not get the recognition due him. He also points out that he, Lambert, was the only one who volunteered to care for patients.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Albert E. Truby, February 4, 1950
div1.opener:
121 Morris Blvd.
Birmingham, Alabama
February 4, 1950
Gen. Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, Calif.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
It took me a long time to get the name of the man who was supposed to take
care of work while Dr. Ames was sick. I attended V.F.W. convention at
Miami, then went over to Havana. On my way back I visited Hanberry who
gave me the clipping which I had photographed. Hundreds of thousands
might have read the article and though Mazzuri a wonderful man. Dr.
Hench told me that General Order 83 did not make Dr. Ames a member of the
Board in place of Dr. Lazear, but only the physician. Could it have been
necessary for Maj. Reed to ask for Dr. Ames's service when he had already
had charge of yellow fever hospital during the epidemic? Even treated two
members of the Board and the first authentic case “Dean!” Was it not
rather for the part each one played in making the experiment a success that
honors were bestowed? If membership in the Board was all that was needed
in order to be honored, then I can honestly say Agramonti got his medal
easy! I know there are hospitals, university buildings, statues, and
monuments and other things erected to honor men who took part in the work,
but for Dr. Ames not as much as a little stone to mark his last resting
place. I have visited at his grave in one of the cemeteries in New Orleans.
If Maj. Reed did not ask for Dr. Ames to be a member of the Board I can't
see why he went out to Camp Lazear. His work as a physician was at the
hospital.

Has a physician the right to innoculate a man with disease just for the fun
of seeing if he can cure him later on? Dr. Ames did so. I helped when
Jernegan received innoculation from Martinez and, General, you would surely
have thought attending physicians under your command had lost their minds
if you had found them feeding mosquitos on their patients just for a
pastime, Dr. Ames was the only one that fed mosquitos down in our hospital.
After Dr. Carroll tried to feed on the first Spaniard and was kicked in the
belly by the man, he never tried again. If Dr. Ames had been unlucky in
his treatment like the doctors at Pinar Del Rio where they had several
deaths and diagnosed these cases as pernicious malaria (you will recall
that happened about three weeks before we started the Yellow Fever Hospital
at Quemados) or as told in the book “Major Reed and Yellow Fever” by
Dr. Kelly. It is stated by Nurse Werner that Maj. Gorgas lost only five
cases the week she was there (Page 236) or as the bad luck they again had
at Las Animas in August, when the world's greatest expert (?) Guiteras took
part. I am certain that none would have offered themselves as guinea pigs
if Dr. Ames had lost only two or three during the summer, even though $200
was a big sum of money in those days!

General, you told me in one of your letters you were a Mason. If so, I know
you have sworn not to let a wrong be done to a man if you could prevent
it. I can't help thinking that a wrong was done to Brother Ames. Neither
can I help thinking that only a word from you could correct that injustice.
I will always believe that Dr. Ames's unusual ability of quick diagnosis
and treatment made the experiment possible.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully yours, Gust E. Lambert (Continued)
-2-
P. S. I enclose some pictures I took while in Havana Hospital with grounds
where Columbia Hospital used to be, Monument of Dr. Finley standing as
near as I could figure out where Dr. Lazear's laboratory used to stand
and statue of Dr. Finley in Collins Park, Miami, Florida.
General Order 83 was not found with Dr. Ames's service record but in
Day Book from General Lee's Headquarters found in the archives.
For myself - I know Major Reed would not have innoculated anyone with
yellow fever except if he knew there was someone to care for the patient.
I was the only one to volunteer.
No need to return.
Lambert
